messages: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:05): will start posting detailed review comments to public-html

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:28): i'll start with the DOM
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:29): today is item() vs namedItem() using [] syntax on htmlcollections
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:30): i wonder how the editors will find the detailed reviews
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:30): Hixie said that anything that isn't in the wiki will be ignored
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:31): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I put "detailed review" in the Subject
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:31): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: so when I'm done, I can search for my review emails and collect the URIs
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (11:32): and send to Hixie?

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:45): ah, karl, you trotted out the allegory of the cave ... you should get a special award for that one: first to mention the allegory that can be applied to just about anything ...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:55): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - last part of bikeshed entry in Wikipedia is especially apt
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:55): People stay quiet on technical issues, but when an issue like indentation formatting or naming conventions arises, everyone has an opinion.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:56): hmm, a little too apt ...
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:56): did somebody from public-html add that, I wonder ...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:57): "Even with the discussion about the parser, we weren't talking about the parse."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:00): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the wikipedia entry has not been edited in the last couple of days, at least
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:03): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - yeah, I looked at the history ... looks like whenever it was added, it wasn't recently
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:04): kind of comforting to know the others have the same problem ... share our pain

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:23): "you took a thread about something else and turned it into a discussion about the parser. It wasn't about the parser until you arrived. The confusion was introduced when you made it about the parser. It was about HTML5 UAs (bigger than the parser). " - am I the only one who has lost track of what the thread was supposedly about?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:24): I would send an email asking Robert to summarize the issues in the thread were supposed to be but I'm not sure it's a valuble use of anyone's time.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:24): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: when I brought up the parser, it was pretty clear that the person I was replying to wasn't familiar with the exact relationship of the content models and the parsing algorithm
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:25): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I agree there has been much of that
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:25): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: my main mistake was that I replied to Rob when he posed a question that was addressed to me
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:25): sees the statement, "We are here because we bring certain expertise about this." hmm...
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:25): I'm still trying to work out how someone constructed a testcase with a <table> that "refused to render" in firefox
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:26): did they post the testcase somewhere?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:27): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: dunno. the one I saw rendered *something* in firefox
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:29): does anybody know what rob does? web designer? web developer?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:30): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: he seems to be doing a doctoral thesis about rethinking Marxism
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:31): interesting

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:32): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: oops. I my recollection was wrong. He says he's on the board of a jounal called "rethinking marxism" the title of the doctoral thesis is unknown
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:33): http://www.robburns.com/

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:36): is just wondering where this guy is coming from ... but now just further confused
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:37): wow indeed
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:38): I think that b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea said something a while back about wishing people would find another hobby
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:40): note to self: never always use "consider" instead of "understand" to avoid offending people
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:41): goes write some software
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): writes an email against his better judgement
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:43): Right, time to do something useful, I guess
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:01): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: isn't it fun when people don't read your previous messages to the same thread?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:20): the AAA is going to be very long when written with minimal stack searching...
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:40): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: see my mail to the list, but, short version, in ECMAScript property names are always strings
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:40): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: knowing that will probably make it easier to test what is going on in IE
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:40): it's probably just using a lenient string-to-number conversion to decide if a collection property name is an index, as opposed to the strict Array rule
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:48): i didn't consider testing with commas
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:48): i also made a mistake with Infinity
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:48): i used 0/0 which is NaN, should have used 1/0
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:49): Why not just use infinity?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:49): Number.POSITIVE_INFINITY
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: do I understand correctly that furthest block a descendant of formatting elment in AAA?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): Hixie's reversal of top and bottom and the name "furthest block" make me doubt things
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:50): a bit down it says "If the furthest block has a parent node, then remove the furthest block from its parent node."
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): how could furthes block not have a parent?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): ooh. there's a jump back to step 1
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:51): does that make it possible to have unparented nodes on the stack?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (13:52): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: 1/0 is shorter (but evidently error prone)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:57): is array [] in ECMAScript real array access by number offset of does it do the string dance, too?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:58): the [] operator is just property lookup
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:59): implementations can optimize of course
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (13:59): to avoid converting number to string and back again
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: wow. I learned something new
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:59): this is why I rarely comment in the JS/API threads
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (14:04): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, yeah, that comparison back to the string value of the int i'd overlooked
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (14:04): seems to be what the built-in Array [[Get]] method does tho
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (14:05): hmm, seems i have to loop through all characters...

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (14:08): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: Re: serving the same bytes as different Content-Types. It sucks to tell Sam Ruby or Jacques Distler that it isn't conforming. However, now that we enabled dual conformance, just about everyone else will shoot themselves in the foot if they try to do their own stunts.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (14:09): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: oops, my message got cut off
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (14:10): I meant to add "but it's not a good idea unless you are enough of an expert to understand the ramifications in detail"
